front.title: ACVP Block Cipher Algorithm JSON Specification

author.organization: National Institute of Standards and Technology

abstract.t: This document defines the JSON schema for using block cipher algorithms with the ACVP specification.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Automated Crypto Validation Protocol (ACVP) defines a mechanism to automatically verify the cryptographic implementation of a software or hardware crypto module. The ACVP specification defines how a crypto module communicates with an ACVP server, including crypto capabilities negotiation, session management, authentication, vector processing and more. The ACVP specification does not define algorithm specific JSON constructs for performing the crypto validation. A series of ACVP sub-specifications define the constructs for testing individual crypto algorithms. Each sub-specification addresses a specific class of crypto algorithms. This sub-specification defines the JSON constructs for testing block cipher crypto algorithms using ACVP.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted in RFC 2119.

section.title: Capabilities Registration
section.t: ACVP requires crypto modules to register their capabilities. This allows the crypto module to advertise support for specific algorithms, notifying the ACVP server which algorithms need test vectors generated for the validation process. This section describes the constructs for advertising support of block cipher algorithms to the ACVP server.

The block cipher algorithm capabilities are advertised as JSON objects within the 'algorithms' value of the ACVP registration message. The 'algorithms' value is an array, where each array element is an individual JSON object defined in this section. The 'algorithms' value is part of the 'capability_exchange' element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.
Each block cipher algorithm capability advertised is a self-contained JSON object.

section.title: Required Prerequisite Algorithms for Block Cipher Validations
section.t: Some block cipher algorithm implementations rely on other cryptographic primitives. For example, CCM uses an underlying AES algorithm. Each of these underlying algorithm primitives must be validated, either separately or as part of the same submission. ACVP provides a mechanism for specifying the required prerequisites:

texttable.title: Required Prerequisite Algorithms JSON Values
texttable.c: object with algorithm and valValue properties

section.title: Block Cipher Algorithm Capabilities JSON Values
section.t: Each algorithm capability advertised is a self-contained JSON object using the following values.

texttable.title: Block Cipher Algorithm Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: The block cipher algorithm and mode to be validated.
The supported key lengths in bits
The supported plain and cipher text lengths in bits. This varies depending on the algorithm type, for additional details see
The supported IV/Nonce lengths in bits, see
IV generation method for AES-GCM/AES-XPN algorithms
IV generation mode for AES-GCM/AES-XPN algorithms
Salt generation method for AES-XPN mode only.
The supported AAD lengths in bits for AEAD algorithms,
The supported Tag lengths in bits for AEAD algorithms,
The cipher as defined in SP800-38F for key wrap mode
The format of tweak value input for AES-XTS
Any non-empty subset of {"hex", "number"}. Hex refers to the tweakValue being a literal hex string. Number refers to the tweakValue being an integer number represented as hex.

The Keying Option used in TDES.
Keying option 1 (1) is 3 distinct keys (K1, K2, K3). Keying Option 2 (2) is 2 distinct only suitable for decrypt (K1, K2, K1). Keying option 3 (No longer valid for testing, save KATs) is a single key, now deprecated (K1, K1, K1).
Indicates if the implementation can handle a counter exceeding the maximum value
Indicates if the implementation increments the counter (versus decrementing the counter)

section.t: Note: Some optional values are required depending on the algorithm. For example, AES-GCM requires ivLen, ivGen, ivGenMode, aadLen and tagLen. Failure to provide these values will result in the ACVP server returning an error to the ACVP client during registration.

section.title: Data, IV and AAD Lengths
section.t: Some algorithms allow ranges of data, IV and AAD lengths. This table outlines the allowed values.

texttable.title: Block Cipher Algorithm Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: Range of values {Min: 0, Max: 256, Increment: 8} minimum greater than or equal to zero and maximum less than or equal to 256.
Range of values {Min: 56, Max: 104, Increment: 8} (represents 7 to 13 bytes)
Range of values {Min: 32, Max: 128, Increment: 16} (represents from 4 to 16 bytes, even values only)
Range of values minimum greater than or equal to zero and maximum less than or equal to 524,288 (2^16)*8)
Array to include, if supported, zero, two values divisible by 128 and two values not divisible by 128
Array one to three values between 8 and 1024
Array to include, if supported, zero, two values divisible by 128 and two values not divisible by 128
Array to include, if supported, zero, two values divisible by 128 and two values not divisible by 128. Followed by the maximum data length not to exceed 2^20

Range of valid data lengths from one to the block size of 128. Explicitly {Min: 1, Max: 128} with any supported increment. For example if only the byte boundaries are supported for the stream cipher, this would appear as {Min: 8, Max: 128, Increment: 8}. The value 128 must appear in this range.

Range of valid data lengths from one to the block size of 64. Explicitly {Min: 1, Max: 64} with any supported increment. For example if only the byte boundaries are supported for the stream cipher, this would appear as {Min: 8, Max: 64, Increment: 8}. The value 64 must appear in this range.

section.title: Supported Block Cipher Algorithms
section.t: The following block cipher algorithms may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

section.title: Test Vectors
section.t: The ACVP server provides test vectors to the ACVP client, which are then processed and returned to the ACVP server for validation. A typical ACVP validation session would require multiple test vector sets to be downloaded and processed by the ACVP client. Each test vector set represents an individual crypto algorithm, such as AES-ECB, AES-CBC, AES-CTR, AES-GCM, TDES-CBC, TDES-CTR, etc. This section describes the JSON schema for a test vector set used with block cipher algorithms.

The test vector set JSON schema is a multi-level hierarchy that contains meta data for the entire vector set as well as individual test vectors to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements at the top level of the hierarchy.

texttable.title: Vector Set JSON Object
texttable.c: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
The block cipher algorithm and mode used for the test vectors. See for possible values.
Array of test group JSON objects, which are defined in

section.title: Test Groups JSON Schema
section.t: The testGroups element at the top level in the test vector JSON object is an array of test groups. Test vectors are grouped into similar test cases to reduce the amount of data transmitted in the vector set. For instance, all test vectors that use the same key size would be grouped together. The Test Group JSON object contains meta data that applies to all test vectors within the group. The following table describes the JSON elements of the Test Group JSON object.

texttable.title: Test Group JSON Object
texttable.c: The IUT processing direction: encrypt or decrypt
IV generation method (Required for AES-GCM and AES-XPN)
IV generation method (Required for AES-GCM and AES-XPN w/ internal ivGen)
Length of key in bits to use
Length of IV in bits to use
Length of plaintext in bits to use
Length of AAD in bits to use
Length of AEAD tag in bits to use
The test category type (AFT, MCT or counter). See for more information about what these tests do, and how to implement them.
Array of individual test vector JSON objects, which are defined in

section.title: Test Case JSON Schema
section.t: Each test group contains an array of one or more test cases. Each test case is a JSON object that represents a single vector to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements for each test case.

texttable.title: Test Case JSON Object
texttable.c: Numeric identifier for the test case, unique across the entire vector set.
Encryption keys to use for TDES
tweakValue used to form an IV for AES-XTS
The salt to use in AES-XPN (required for AES-XPN only)
Plaintext Length to use in bits. When unspecified, it will be infered from the plaintext. When specified, only the most significant 'ptLen' bits will be used.
Ciphertext Length to use in bits. When unspecified, it will be infered from the ciphertext. When specified, only the most significant 'ctLen' bits will be used.
AAD to use for AEAD algorithms
Tag to use for AEAD algorithms
Array of IVs used in a Counter implementation

section.title: Test Vector Responses
section.t: After the ACVP client downloads and processes a vector set, it must send the response vectors back to the ACVP server. The following table describes the JSON object that represents a vector set response.

texttable.title: Vector Set Response JSON Object
texttable.c: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
Array of JSON objects that represent each test vector result, which uses the same JSON schema as defined in

Some test cases included with decrypt operations in AES-GCM, AES-CCM, AES-XPN, AES-KW, AES-KWP, and TDES-KW will have expected failures. For these cases the JSON reponse should include the decryptFail keyword, see
Array of JSON objects that represent each iteration of a Monte Carlo Test. Each iteration will contain the key(s), pt, ct and iv (except for ECB mode)

section.title: Test Types and Test Coverage
section.t:
The ACVP server performs a set of tests on the block ciphers in order to assess the correctness and robustness of the implementation. A typical ACVP validation session would require multiple tests to be performed for every supported cryptographic algorithm, such as AES-ECB, AES-CBC, AES-CTR, AES-GCM, TDES-CBC, TDES-CTR, etc. This section describes the design of the tests used to validate implementations of block cipher algorithms. There are three types of tests for block ciphers: functional tests, Monte Carlo tests and counter tests. Each has a specific value to be used in the testType field. The testType field definitions are:
"AFT" - Algorithm Functional Test. These tests can be processed by the client using a normal 'encrypt' or 'decrypt' operation. AFTs cause the implentation under test to exercise normal operations whether single block, multiple blocks, or (where applicable) partial blocks. In some cases random data is used, in others, static, predetermined tests are provided. The functional tests of the block cipher are designed to verify that the logical components of the cipher (GFSbox, KeySbox, block chaining etc.) are operating correctly. "MCT" - Monte Carlo Test. These tests exercise the implentation under test under strenuous circumstances. The implementation under test must process the test vectors according to the correct algorithm and mode in this document. MCTs can help detect potential memory leaks over time, and problems in allocation of resources, addressing variables, error handling and generally improper behavior in response to random inputs. Each MCT processes 100 pseudorandom tests. Not every algorithm and mode combination has an MCT. See for implementation details. "Counter" - Counter Mode Test. Counter tests are specifically for counter modes (AES-MCT and TDES-MCT) and require an implementation under test to exercise their counter mechanism. The server will send a long message to the client for encryption or decryption and back-compute the counters used by the implementation under test. These counters are then verified for uniqueness and an increasing (or decreasing) nature. The client processes these tests as normal AFTs. The different mode is highlighted here to signify the difference on the server side for processing.

section.title: Monte Carlo tests for block ciphers
section.t: The MCT start with an initial condition (plain/cipher text, key, and optional, or maybe multiple IVs) and perform a series of chained calculation. For modes that use an IV, the IV is used in the beginning of each pseudorandom process. There are separate rounds of MCT for encryption and decryption. Because some block cipher modes rely on an IV and perform calculations differently from other modes, there are specific definitions of MCT for many of the block cipher modes.

Note: For all the following, the pseudocode for decryption can be obtained by replacing all PT's with CT's and all CT's with PT's. As well, replace the encrypt operation with the corresponding decrypt operation.

section.title: AES Monte Carlo Test - ECB mode
section.t: The initial condition for the test is the tuple (KEY, PT) set to some values.
The algorithm is shown in .

figure.artwork: Key[0] = KEY PT[0] = PT For i = 0 to 99 Output Key[i] Output PT[0] For j = 0 to 999 CT[j] = AES_ECB_ENCRYPT(Key[i], PT[j]) PT[j+1] = CT[j] Output CT[j] AES_KEY_SHUFFLE(Key, CT) PT[0] = CT[j]

section.title: AES Monte Carlo Test - CBC mode
section.t: The initial condition for the test is the tuple (KEY, IV, PT) set to some values.
The algorithm is shown in .

figure.artwork: Key[0] = KEY IV[0] = IV PT[0] = PT For i = 0 to 99 Output Key[i] Output IV[i] Output PT[0] For j = 0 to 999 If ( j=0 ) CT[j] = AES_CBC_ENCRYPT(Key[i], IV[i], PT[j]) PT[j+1] = IV[i] Else CT[j] = AES_CBC_ENCRYPT(Key[i], PT[j]) PT[j+1] = CT[j-1] Output CT[j] AES_KEY_SHUFFLE(Key, CT) IV[i+1] = CT[j] PT[0] = CT[j-1]

section.title: AES Monte Carlo Test - OFB mode
section.t: The initial condition for the test is the tuple (KEY, IV, PT) set to some values.
The algorithm is shown in .

figure.artwork: Key[0] = Key IV[0] = IV PT[0] = PT For i = 0 to 99 Output Key[i] Output IV[i] Output PT[0] For j = 0 to 999 If ( j=0 ) CT[j] = AES_OFB_ENCRYPT(Key[i], IV[i], PT[j]) PT[j+1] = IV[i] Else CT[j] = AES_OFB_ENCRYPT(Key[i], PT[j]) PT[j+1] = CT[j-1] Output CT[j] AES_KEY_SHUFFLE(Key, CT) IV[i+1] = CT[j] PT[0] = CT[j-1]

section.title: AES Monte Carlo Test - CFB1 mode
AES Monte Carlo Test - CFB8 mode
AES Monte Carlo Test - CFB128 mode
AES Monte Carlo Key Shuffle
section.t: Most AES MCTs use a shared key shuffle routine. The algorithm is shown in . The initial condition for the routine is a tuple (KEY, CT) set to some values. This pseudocode is specifically for encryption. For decryption, swap all instances of CT with PT.

figure.artwork: If ( keylen = 128 ) Key[i+1] = Key[i] xor CT[j] If ( keylen = 192 ) Key[i+1] = Key[i] xor (last 64-bits of CT[j-1] || CT[j]) If ( keylen = 256 ) Key[i+1] = Key[i] xor (CT[j-1] || CT[j])

section.title: TDES Monte Carlo Test - ECB mode
TDES Monte Carlo Test - CBC mode
TDES Monte Carlo Test - CBC-I mode
TDES Monte Carlo Test - CFB mode
TDES Monte Carlo Test - CFB-P mode
TDES Monte Carlo Test - OFB mode
TDES Monte Carlo Test - OFB-I mode
Test Coverage

section.t: This memo includes no request to IANA.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Security considerations are addressed by the ACVP specification.

section.title: Example TDES Test and Results JSON Object
section.t: The following is a example JSON object for test vectors sent from the ACVP server to the crypto module for an TDES-ECB algorithm functional test.
The following is a example JSON object for test results sent from the crypto module to the ACVP server for an TDES-ECB algorithm functional test.
The following is a example JSON object for test vectors sent from the ACVP server to the crypto module for the TDES-CFB1 algorithm functional test.
The following is a example JSON object for test results sent from the crypto module to the ACVP server for an TDES-CFB1 algorithm functional test.

section.title: Example TDES MCT Test and Results JSON Object
section.t: The following is a example JSON object for test vectors sent from the ACVP server to the crypto module for an TDES-ECB Monte Carlo test.

The following is a example JSON object for test results sent from the crypto module to the ACVP server for an TDES-ECB Monte Carlo test, only 2 iterations shown for brevity. For MCT results of each iteration are fed into the next iteration. Therefore the results carry all fields to assist in any failure diagnosis.

section.title: Example Test Results JSON Object
section.t: An example of the test results format from an AES-GCM decrypt operation including failure case.

section.title: Example Test Prompt CTR JSON Object
section.t: An example of the test format sent from the server to the client for an AES-CTR encrypt operation.

section.title: Example Test Results CTR JSON Object
section.t: An example of the test results format from an AES-CTR encrypt operation.
